page.title: 02Valley - landscape
page.content: The deep and steep sided valley of the Trout beck is the dominant feature of the area (although "river" gives a more accurate indication of its size than "beck"). The land rises steadily on its western side from the valley floor at about 120m., via Troutbeck village at about 180m. to over 350m. above sea level. The eastern slope is steeper, rising in the same distance to over 475m. As in the rest of the Lake District, glaciation has had a marked effect on landscape. The valley has the usual U-shaped cross section although the floor is choked with moraine deposits especially in the south. It widens towards the north as an old lake bed is approached. There is a marked contrast between the rough grazing above the village and the improved pasture below it.
